titlestmt.titleproper: International Union of Physiological Sciences Records 1889-1989 Mss.610.6.In82

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-13T18:21-0400

did.unittitle: International Union of Physiological Sciences Records
did.abstract:
To promote the science of physiology and the exchange of ideas, the first congress of the International Union of Physiological Sciences (IUPS) was held in Basle, Switzerland, in 1889, and congresses have been held every three years since. The Union was incorporated at Washington, D.C., in 1953.
The bulk of the Records of the IUPS relate to the International Congresses. Although representation is uneven, with a gap between 1907-1920, the records include programs, lists of members, abstracts of communications, and photographs, with more substantial documentation for meetings held in the United States. The collection also includes some general correspondence, minutes of meetings, reports of the Secretary, Executive Committee and Council correspondence, records relating to budgets, record books, and photographs.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: International Union of Physiological Sciences. Congress

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection is organized in the following series:

list.item:
V. Photographs
A. Congress Photographs
B. Other Photographs

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Gift of the IUPS, initially through Wallace Fenn, John Hubbard and Maurice Visscher, 1969-1980.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Cite as: International Union of Physiological Sciences Records, American Philosophical Society.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The International Union of Physiological Sciences (IUPS) was incorporated in 1953 at Washington, D.C., formalizing an earlier practice of persons in or interested in Physiological Science organizing international congresses around the core of Physiological Science. The purpose was to exchange, promote and further the knowledge of Physiological Science throughout the world. The first congress was held in 1889.

Membership is extended, not to individual scientists, but to national societies, unions, committees, academies or organizations from around the world. The members, called Adhering Societies, have a direct or sometimes related interest in Physiological Science.

The International Union of Physiological Sciences is not a professional association in the usual sense, organizing professional meetings from time to time. Rather, the meetings, or as they are called "Congresses", are the International Union of Physiological Sciences.

The organizing arrangement considers the incorporation of the IUPS the institutionalization of an earlier procedure for establishing and calling Congresses through a body of persons called "The Permanent Committee." This apparently evolved into the present functions of the "Executive Committee and the "Council." One or both of these bodies may establish, from time to time, an organizing committee for a particular congress. This was obviously done in the case of the XXIV Congress held in Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The documents in this series represent the Congresses somewhat unevenly. The XXIV Congress held in Washington, D.C. in 1968 is most comprehensively documented. The files of the earlier Congresses are less complete.

By the nature of the IUPS it is obvious that some correspondence in the Congresses Series and some in the Executive/Council Series could be interchangeable. In some instances a letter was found to be in both files. Rather than solve an organizational imponderable, the rationale of the files' organization was to accept what had been received as Congresses correspondence, as a Congress document, even though it could also have been an Executive/Council document.
Otherwise the Congresses files, expand or not, as the existing material may or may not permit division into various subdivisions, such as:

Series II - Adhering Societies/Union International Unions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Initially, this series contains material about member organizations, such as correspondence, activities and background information. However, it is not limited to members, but includes "supporting societies" and any organization or body that has a declared interest in the work of the congresses. In some instances those bodies are themselves other scientific unions. Material pertaining to IUPS Regional Meetings and/or Symposia that appear to be inspired by the activities of the Adhering Society or Supporting Society and are not clearly a part of a congress are also organized in this series.
Those symposia or satellite meetings or even regional meetings that appear to be clearly a part of a congress are filed together with that congress.

The United States is represented in the Adhering Societies/Union International Unions series under the heading: U.S. Committee. In fact, the U.S. Committee appears to be a function of the National Academy of Sciences, which technically would be the Adhering Society. The National Academy of Sciences, however, appears to have considerable expanse in its interests. Therefore, in order to collect the substantive aspect of the participation as a member of the IUPS, there is simply a file section titled "U.S. Committee" in this series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Based on earlier statements about the "Permanent Committee," this series begins with the files of the "Permanent Committee."

Unfortunately, most of the material in the Executive/Council Series has been signed without the title of the author. It is apparent, in the case of some individuals, that they held more than one office at various times. Without an inscribed title under their name, their office at the time of writing is not necessarily known. Therefore, this series is mostly a chronological correspondence file.
There did emerge from this material certain documents that were easily categorized. They are:

list.item: Treasurer's Reports and Accounts (Includes Auditor's Reports)

scopecontent.p: Archivist's files and a publication called "Newsletter" material are also filed under their separate identities in the Executive/Council series. These were included because their functions appear to be the responsibility of the Executive/Council whether or not the offices of the Archivist and Editor of the Newsletter were in themselves necessarily Executive Committee or Council positions.
The Executive/Council series does not include the correspondence of the officers of a particular congress, since each congress has its own officers named for that Congress only.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Congresses and/or the Executive/Council established various commissions or committees for specific purposes. While the commission or committee may report in due course to a congress or to the Executive/Council or both, some function in a time span greater than a congress or an Executive/Council meeting. Hence, this work was collected in a separate series whenever the commission or committee was seen to be established by the IUPS.
Items relating to a committee or commission which appeared to be established by an Adhering Society or equal were filed together with the Adhering Society in Series II.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In some instances, congresses were commemorated with photographs which in themselves are not the content of the congress or about the bureaucratic activity of the congress, such as the correspondence may be, but simply a visual record of the culture of the congress.
Hence, photographs of all congresses have been collected under a separate series and are not included in the Congresses Series.
Sometimes other meetings or individuals in the IUPS are also documented in photographs. Therefore, the Photographs Series is further divided into subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains books, papers or statements which record collective histories or selective histories of the IUPS.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The congresses were also commemorated with medals, cultural programs, tours, and the like which, like the photographs, are not directly the content of the congress, but are part of the experience of attending a congress. Like the photographs, these materials and objects have been collected in their own series.

did.unittitle: Certificate Issued to Wallace O. Fenn Designating Him Chairman and Delegate XXI Congress - Buenos Aires
Some Dutch Contributions to the Development of Physiology
The Way of the Investigator (Walter B. Cannon)
Miscellaneous Brochures, Cards, Maps, Tickets, Etc.
Series VIII - Bound Correspondence and Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence and other material that had been bound together (before the archives came to the American Philosophical Society) and such collected information that would have been otherwise filed under other series. Archivists at the APS decided not to disbind these volumes and file the documents into their proper places in the series described above, so it is therefore necessary to use the contents of these bound volumes in conjunction with related documents from other series.
